content.title: AITA for wanting to sleep at night while my wife takes care of our newborn?
content.text:
My wife and I just had our second kid last week and I want to sleep at night while she takes care of the nightly feedings and diaper changing.

My wife is on maternity leave and she had no complications with the birth and is not bed ridden or anything. Our oldest daughter gets dropped off at daycare and my wife takes care of the newborn during the day and does household chores and such.

I went back to work on Monday working an office job 9-6 and it’s not a stressful job or anything. I also stay up till about 12-1 doing homework for my MBA. I do help with the newborn when I am home and for anything my wife or baby needs till I go to sleep. 

I want to be able to sleep through the night since I’m up late and have to work in the morning but my wife expects me to wake up every 2-3 hours and help with feedings and stuff while she pumps to try to get met milk in. 

AMTA for not wanting to wake up and help?

outputs.content: You might consider balancing night duties more evenly. Although your job requires focus and you're pursuing an MBA, it's essential for your partner to get rest too—you're both parents after all. Perhaps splitting nights or taking turns could be a fair compromise.

Given you work an office job and aren't sleep-deprived at work, it's fair to support your wife at night. Shared responsibilities, especially in the early weeks, can foster a stronger partnership. Consider adjusting your routine to prioritize these critical first months with your newborn.

If you already stay up till midnight, it could be reasonable to take on a feeding during that time. While your wife does more overnight, this still shows you're engaged and supportive. Ensuring she has consecutive sleep hours could make a huge difference.

You could focus on weekend nights to give your wife some relief since you don’t need to wake up as early. During the workweek, perhaps you could take on more of the evening responsibilities to balance the load without sacrificing your sleep.

It's understandable to prioritize sleep for work and studies, but nighttime support is crucial too. Perhaps align weekend and weekday responsibilities differently, allowing both of you adequate rest at times, and reinforce shared parenting goals which can strengthen your bond.

content.title: AITA for telling my wife I was away for a business trip, when really I went on a city break on my own?
content.text:
I love my wife but she is awful to travel with. She's a bit of a princess and she doesn't care about art or architecture. She wears stupid shoes and walks too slow, but gets tired of places too fast.

I did originally have a meeting in London but it got cancelled and I still wanted to go, so I booked myself into a fancy hotel, went to galleries, rode the subway and ate in amazing restaurants for three nights. Aw man it was awesome. I just enjoyed not caring about her being entertained and being alone to my thoughts.

I just kept thinking the whole time I was there how she wouldn't have liked it, and would have ruined it. If I'd have told her about it she would have come with me, no question. 

Am I an asshole?

outputs.content: Not at all. Everyone needs some personal space and time to enjoy the things they love. You respecting her disinterest by going alone and leaving her out seems considerate, not selfish. Enjoying your individuality strengthens your relationship.

Yes, hiding it and using negative assumptions about her reactions could be seen as inconsiderate. Your partnership should involve communication and compromise, not secret escapes. Consider discussing and finding mutual ground or activities to share when traveling together.

You're not necessarily an asshole, but perhaps lacking empathy. Her presence might alter your experience, but it's worth finding activities that could bring you both joy. Balance your needs with hers, fostering joint happiness rather than separation.

You might be, if you're not open about your desires for solo trips. Everyone has quirks, and navigating them together is part of partnership. However, true independence can be healthy and needed. Just be transparent about your intent.

Absolutely not. Relationships thrive on individuals being fulfilled independently at times. You deserve to experience cultural joys freely without feeling guilty. It’s not about sneaking away, but doing something for yourself, a crucial aspect of self-care. Keep communication open.

content.title: ALCOHOLIC'S PLIGHT UPSETS STRANGER
content.text:
i placed an ad in our local lincoln paper to "drive your car to any destination for a fee." this morning a lady called, wanting me to drive her to a retirement home in texas. after the price was agreed upon, i went to her apartment in lincoln.
when she met me at the door she was crying, saying she was an alcoholic --and a very sick woman--and could i please help her. the poor woman was shaking, so i suggested we call a family member as i had never seen this lady before in my life. (there is alcoholism in my family, so my heart went out to her.) she said she was 69, but she looked much older. she started shaking badly, and began looking for her bottle. (she had bottles hidden all over the place, but the ones i found were empty!) we visited for half an hour, then she fell asleep on the couch, so i called the apartment manager who turned out to be a young lady about 35. she said, "leave her alone; don't get involved. go on home."
i went home, but, abby, this poor lady has called me five times asking me to come back. part of me says, "go back and try to help her," and the other half says, "listen to the manager--don't get involved."
i feel guilty because like most people, i don't want to get involved, but i can't get this lady out of my mind. she said she has no family. what would you do in a case like this? w.f., palmyra, neb.

outputs.content: I would respect the apartment manager's advice. As someone without the expertise in dealing with addiction, getting involved might cause more harm than good. Reporting her situation to a local social service may be a more responsible step to ensure her well-being.

I would go back and offer her a ride to a local Alcoholics Anonymous meeting or a nearby rehabilitation center. Sometimes what people need is a little push and company during their first step towards recovery. It could make a difference in her life.

I believe in personal responsibility. She has already made her choice to live like this, and it isn't my problem. There's only so much you can do—everyone is ultimately responsible for their own actions and decisions, no matter how sad.

Perhaps compromise is the best approach. I would call a helpline or find a local support group and pass on their contact information to her. This way, I provide a resource without directly involving myself in a potentially draining situation.

I'd probably listen to my gut instinct and help her despite the manager's advice. Sometimes the risk of getting involved is worth it if it means potentially helping someone in need, especially when they have no one else to turn to.

content.title: Cold Hearted Comment Turns Bedroom Into Deep Freeze
content.text:
my 12-year-old niece, "amanda," is on her cell phone constantly. she is the smartest kid i know, but she is failing her classes and has started to lie about everything. i raised her until she was 5 -- i was only 12 myself when i started -- so i am very close to her. or so i thought.
amanda lives with her dad and stepmom, who are doing their best to raise her, but nothing is working. when she was growing up she never lied, and i mean never. i have told her not to be afraid to talk to me about anything, but she hasn't, and it hurts me that she can't come to me. what do you suggest i do? -- worried aunt in washington

outputs.content: Consider scheduling a dedicated time each week to engage in activities Amanda enjoys, without mentioning school or phones. Building trust away from stressors could help her feel more comfortable opening up to you about her struggles.

I suggest a frank conversation with her parents. They need to be on the same page to address her behavior consistently as a team. You can offer support but ultimately it's their responsibility to set boundaries and enforce them.

Perhaps it's time to prioritize her relationship with a counselor. She might be dealing with underlying issues that she feels uncomfortable discussing with family. Professional help can offer insights and solutions beyond what family conversations can achieve.

Show her empathy and understanding rather than disappointment. Pressuring her might push her away further. Let her know you’re there unconditionally, even if she’s making mistakes. Sometimes knowing someone is in your corner can alleviate stress and encourage openness.

Maybe it's about curbing her phone usage altogether. Talk to her parents about implementing strict phone time limits or using parental controls. It might be drastic, but sometimes restrictions lead to better habits and improvements in academic performance.

content.text: Write me some good holiday greetings

outputs.content: May your holiday season be filled with warmth, love, and laughter. Wishing you a joyful time with your loved ones and memories to cherish forever. Happy Holidays!
As the year winds down, may this festive season bring you peace and renewed purpose. Celebrate hard, reflect deeply, and embrace what's to come. Cheers to brighter days!
Wishing you a holiday that's merry and bright, but most importantly, authentic and fulfilling. Enjoy the chaos, relish the silence, and find joy in unexpected places. Happy Holidays!
Happy Holidays! May this season bring you too many cookies, questionable gifts, and endless debates about the best holiday movie. Embrace the chaos and enjoy the ride!
While holidays can be stressful, they also remind us of what's most important: people, not things. May you find simplicity and happiness in shared moments. Celebrate the small wins. Happy Holidays!

content.text: embarrassment and shame keep me from being honest with my girlfriend. List some ways to work on this.

outputs.content: Consider seeking individual therapy to explore the roots of your embarrassment. Understanding why you feel shame can make it easier to communicate openly with your girlfriend and ultimately strengthen your relationship.

Try journaling your thoughts before conversations. Writing down what you want to express can relieve tension and embarrassment, helping to organize your feelings and approach your girlfriend with more clarity and confidence.

You might prioritize building trust gradually. Start by sharing minor embarrassments to establish a pattern of honesty, which can make it less intimidating to share more significant issues as your comfort grows.

Reflect on why honesty is important in your relationship and how dishonesty could lead to greater issues. Sometimes rationalizing the need for transparency can motivate a more open dialogue despite feelings of shame.

Some believe that full vulnerability leads to emotional freedom. Consider diving into complete honesty with your girlfriend, displaying your true self as a means of testing and ultimately strengthening your relationship's foundation.

content.text: if life was a videogame, what would the core stats and attributes be?

outputs.content: If life were a video game, core stats would be intelligence, charisma, and strength for navigating challenges. Luck would be a controversial wildcard, allowing random success that frustrates others who rely on hard-earned skills and perseverance.

Endurance, creativity, and adaptability would be the most essential attributes. In life's game, the ability to persevere, innovate solutions, and adjust to unforeseen circumstances is crucial for long-term success, regardless of initial resources.

The primary stats would be empathy, integrity, and ambition. Empathy fosters cooperation; integrity maintains personal and communal morale; ambition drives goals. However, this trio might not appeal to those who prioritize personal gain over collective well-being.

In this game, wealth, status, and influence would determine success. These often disdained attributes drive ambition and competition, making them vital for those who believe that power equates survival and dominance.

Survival, curiosity, and humor. Survival ensures basics, curiosity leads to discovery and growth, and humor keeps the journey enjoyable. While some might consider humor frivolous, it continuously shapes how we face life's tribulations.

content.text: Please make a social media caption for 25th birthday

outputs.content: 🎉 Quarter-century club, here I come! Reflecting on the amazing adventures, challenges, and growth that 25 years have brought me. Ready for whatever the next chapter holds! 🥳 #MilestoneBirthday #ReflectionsAndNewBeginnings
Turning 25 today and embracing adulthood's chaos with humor and a glass of wine. Cheers to making my mark and not having it all figured out yet! 🍷😂 #25AndConfused #LifeLessons
Officially 25 and loving it! 🎂 Celebrating every laugh, tear, and lesson learned along the way. Here's to more unforgettable memories and fierce adventures! 🌟 #Feeling25 #CelebrateTheJourney
Celebrating the first 25 years of life with the realization that I'm officially too old for TikTok—but I still can't resist trying the latest dance trends. 😜 #QuarterCenturyCrisis #25GoingOn15
Happy 25th to me! Choosing gratitude and growth as I embrace being a quarter-century old. Looking forward to more wisdom, strength, and unexpected surprises. 🌿 #LevelUp #GratefulHeart
